message.content: hello claude! i think i remember a time when i hade to change settings in claude code to let you run your agents in parallel? could you check your official docs for this

content.text: I'll check the official Claude Code documentation about running agents in parallel.

input.prompt: Find information about running agents in parallel and any settings or configuration required for parallel agent execution

content.content:
Based on the documentation, here are the key details about running agents in parallel:

In the Subagents section, the documentation provides insights into parallel agent execution:

1. Benefits of Subagents include:
- "Parallelization"
- "Context Management"
- "Specialized Instructions and Knowledge"

2. Subagent Invocation Patterns:
- Automatic Invocation
- Explicit Invocation

3. SDK Integration for Subagents:
The SDK supports two primary ways of using subagents:
- Automatic delegation
- Explicit invocation of specific subagents

4. Advanced Usage:
The documentation mentions "Chaining subagents" and "Dynamic subagent selection" as advanced techniques for parallel or sequential agent interactions.

While the documentation provides a framework for parallel agent execution, it doesn't provide extremely detailed step-by-step instructions for setting up parallel agents. Users would likely need to configure subagents in their configuration files and use the SDK's subagent features to implement parallel execution.

I'll search for information about Claude Code parallel agents configuration settings on the Anthropic documentation site.

Links: [{"title":"Claude Code settings - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings"},{"title":"Subagents - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents"},{"title":"Claude Code overview - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview"},{"title":"Set up Claude Code - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup"},{"title":"Claude Code SDK - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk"},{"title":"Claude Code tutorials - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/agents-and-tools/claude-code/tutorials"},{"title":"Claude Code GitHub Actions - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/github-actions"},{"title":"Claude Code SDK","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk/sdk-overview"},{"title":"Troubleshooting - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting"},{"title":"Connect Claude Code to tools via MCP - Anthropic","url":"https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/mcp"}]

Based on the search results from the Anthropic documentation, I can provide you with information about Claude Code's parallel agents configuration settings:

## Claude Code Parallel Agents Configuration

Claude Code supports custom subagents (specialized AI assistants) that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window. Subagents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to.

### Key Configuration Points for Parallel Work:

1. **Subagent Configuration**: Claude Code supports custom AI subagents that can be configured at both user and project levels. These subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter: User subagents: ~/.claude/agents/ - Available across all your projects · Project subagents: .claude/agents/ - Specific to your project and can be shared with your team

2. **Context Isolation**: Each subagent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives. This is crucial for parallel processing as it ensures agents don't interfere with each other.

3. **Tool Configuration**: Subagents can be granted access to any of Claude Code's internal tools. You have two options for configuring tools: Omit the tools field to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools · Specify individual tools as a comma-separated list for more granular control. When the tools field is omitted, subagents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.

4. **Git Worktrees for Parallel Sessions**: Each worktree has its own independent file state, making it perfect for parallel Claude Code sessions · Changes made in one worktree won't affect others, preventing Claude instances from interfering with each other · All worktrees share the same Git history and remote connections · For long-running tasks, you can have Claude working in one worktree while you continue development in another

### Configuration Settings:

The main configuration settings for parallel agents include:

- **Settings files (JSON)**: Settings files (JSON): Configure permissions, environment variables, and tool behavior
- **Environment variables**: Claude Code supports the following environment variables to control its behavior: All environment variables can also be configured in settings.json. This is useful as a way to automatically set environment variables for each session, or to roll out a set of environment variables for your whole team or organization.
- **Permission rules**: Permission rules can be configured using /allowed-tools or in permission settings.

### Performance Considerations:

Context efficiency: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions · Latency: Subagents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.

The documentation indicates that while Claude Code supports delegation to specialized subagents for parallel task handling, true concurrent execution of multiple agents simultaneously isn't explicitly described. The focus is more on task delegation and context isolation to prevent interference between different workflows.

content.title: Connect Claude Code to tools via MCP - Anthropic

results:
Based on the search results from the Anthropic documentation, I can provide you with information about Claude Code's parallel agents configuration settings:

## Claude Code Parallel Agents Configuration

Claude Code supports custom subagents (specialized AI assistants) that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window. Subagents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to.

### Key Configuration Points for Parallel Work:

1. **Subagent Configuration**: Claude Code supports custom AI subagents that can be configured at both user and project levels. These subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter: User subagents: ~/.claude/agents/ - Available across all your projects · Project subagents: .claude/agents/ - Specific to your project and can be shared with your team

2. **Context Isolation**: Each subagent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives. This is crucial for parallel processing as it ensures agents don't interfere with each other.

3. **Tool Configuration**: Subagents can be granted access to any of Claude Code's internal tools. You have two options for configuring tools: Omit the tools field to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools · Specify individual tools as a comma-separated list for more granular control. When the tools field is omitted, subagents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.

4. **Git Worktrees for Parallel Sessions**: Each worktree has its own independent file state, making it perfect for parallel Claude Code sessions · Changes made in one worktree won't affect others, preventing Claude instances from interfering with each other · All worktrees share the same Git history and remote connections · For long-running tasks, you can have Claude working in one worktree while you continue development in another

### Configuration Settings:

The main configuration settings for parallel agents include:

- **Settings files (JSON)**: Settings files (JSON): Configure permissions, environment variables, and tool behavior
- **Environment variables**: Claude Code supports the following environment variables to control its behavior: All environment variables can also be configured in settings.json. This is useful as a way to automatically set environment variables for each session, or to roll out a set of environment variables for your whole team or organization.
- **Permission rules**: Permission rules can be configured using /allowed-tools or in permission settings.

### Performance Considerations:

Context efficiency: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions · Latency: Subagents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.

The documentation indicates that while Claude Code supports delegation to specialized subagents for parallel task handling, true concurrent execution of multiple agents simultaneously isn't explicitly described. The focus is more on task delegation and context isolation to prevent interference between different workflows.

content.text:
Based on the documentation, I don't see a specific setting for enabling parallel agent execution. However, Claude Code does support:

1. **Subagents** - Specialized agents that can be delegated tasks with their own isolated context
2. **Git Worktrees** - For parallel Claude Code sessions working on different branches

The parallel execution happens automatically when you invoke multiple agents in a single message. To run agents in parallel, you simply need to:

**Send multiple Task tool calls in a single message** rather than separate messages. For example, if you ask me to run multiple agents "in parallel", I'll send them all at once rather than sequentially.

There's no special setting you need to change - it's about how the agents are invoked. The key is requesting multiple agent tasks in one go rather than waiting for each to complete before starting the next.

message.content: how would we test this? please write five famous sentences from a movie in /tmp/{1-5}.txt in parallel?

content.text: I'll write five famous movie quotes to separate files in /tmp/ in parallel using multiple tool calls in a single message.

input.content: May the Force be with you.

toolUseResult.content: May the Force be with you.

content.text: Done! All five files were created in parallel with famous movie quotes. The parallel execution worked - all Write commands were sent in a single message and executed simultaneously.

message.content: now how do we do the same but add 1-5 seconds delay?

content.text: I'll create the files with delays using background bash commands running in parallel. Each command will sleep for a different duration before writing the file.

input.command: sleep 1 && echo "May the Force be with you." > /tmp/1.txt && echo "File 1 created after 1 second"
sleep 2 && echo "I'll be back." > /tmp/2.txt && echo "File 2 created after 2 seconds"
sleep 3 && echo "There's no place like home." > /tmp/3.txt && echo "File 3 created after 3 seconds"
sleep 4 && echo "You can't handle the truth!" > /tmp/4.txt && echo "File 4 created after 4 seconds"
sleep 5 && echo "I see dead people." > /tmp/5.txt && echo "File 5 created after 5 seconds"

content.content: Command running in background with ID: 7115c2
Command running in background with ID: f588ec
Command running in background with ID: 147f7a
Command running in background with ID: 440040
Command running in background with ID: 2d81cc

content.text: All five commands are now running in parallel with staggered delays (1-5 seconds). Let me check their output to confirm completion:

toolUseResult.command: sleep 1 && echo "May the Force be with you." > /tmp/1.txt && echo "File 1 created after 1 second"
sleep 2 && echo "I'll be back." > /tmp/2.txt && echo "File 2 created after 2 seconds"
sleep 3 && echo "There's no place like home." > /tmp/3.txt && echo "File 3 created after 3 seconds"
sleep 4 && echo "You can't handle the truth!" > /tmp/4.txt && echo "File 4 created after 4 seconds"
sleep 5 && echo "I see dead people." > /tmp/5.txt && echo "File 5 created after 5 seconds"

content.text: Perfect! All five background processes completed successfully. The files were created in parallel with their respective delays (1-5 seconds), and each process finished independently. This demonstrates true parallel execution with different completion times.

message.content: perfect. we now know it is working when i tell  you to do it at least :)

content.text:
Exactly! The parallel execution works perfectly when you explicitly ask for it. All five commands ran simultaneously with their different delays, proving that Claude Code can handle true parallel operations when requested. 

The key is in how the request is made - when you ask for parallel execution, I send all the tool calls in a single message rather than sequentially. No special settings needed! :)
